docs.lead_paragraph: The tarnished silver buses that lumber along the avenues of this city are outdated, some of them 20 years old, but the cracked and faded seats are precious to many people. In Montgomery, where Rosa Parks made history by refusing to give her seat to a white passenger on Dec. 1, 1955, these buses are seen not only as a service but also as a civil right. Johnnie Carr, who took part in the bus boycott here in 1955 and 1956, recalled, "I remember that I would be too proud to sit, so I would just stand" rather than face the indignity of having to give up her seat to a white passenger. "I stood all the way home, some days," she added.

headline.main: Buses Again Trouble Civil Rights Veterans

docs.lead_paragraph: A PEEKSKILL-BASED New York State Army National Guard Unit has been called to active duty to participate in Operation Joint Endeavor, the NATO peacekeeping mission in Bosnia. The 133d Maintenance Company was one of 40 Army National Guard and Army Reserve units nationwide mobilized last month to augment or relieve regular Army forces in Europe. The 133d was the only New York State National Guard unit called up. Two Army Reserve units in the state, one from Rochester and one from New York City, were also activated.

headline.main: Peekskill Unit to Help Bosnia Troops

docs.lead_paragraph: HOUR after hour, scarcely pausing between tasks, Mike Darrah sweeps up shards of broken glass from the repair-shop floor in Olympia, Wash., hoists heavy replacement windshields onto car frames and wrestles them into position, then painstakingly seals the rims. Mr. Darrah, a 24-year-old employee of Safelite Glass, a windshield manufacturing and repair company, cannot afford to stop, because he is working on the piece-rate system. A grim reminder that sweatshop capitalism is alive, if not well, in America? A Dickensian vision of where the work force, cowed by corporate downsizing, is heading?

headline.main: Paid by the Widget, and Proud

docs.lead_paragraph: Milio Azcarraga Milmo usually travels with an entourage befitting the most powerful media mogul in Mexico. With his baronial bearing and distinctive appearance -- a stripe of white hair bisects his jet-black mane -- Mr. Azcarraga lives up to his nickname, "El Tigre." On a bright, cold morning in January, however, Mr. Azcarraga turned up alone at the home of Mary Anselmo in Greenwich, Conn. And on that day at least, the tiger acted more like a tabby.

docs.lead_paragraph: An increase in the Federal minimum wage, which seemed to be heading toward passage as recently as last month, has been thrown into jeopardy with the departure of Bob Dole from the Senate, senior Administration officials say. Mr. Dole, who was the Republican leader before he left the Senate to focus on his Presidential campaign, opposed the Democrats' proposal to increase the minimum wage to $5.15 an hour from $4.25, but in late May he said he would be willing to move ahead with a vote.

headline.main: Senate Leadership Change Stalls Minimum-Wage Legislation

docs.lead_paragraph: Bob and Elizabeth Dole have assets worth $2.3 million to $7.7 million, most of which belong to Mrs. Dole, according to a financial report released today by the Senate. The Doles had widely diversified stock, bond and real estate holdings before most of them were placed in two blind trusts last year, after Mr. Dole announced he would seek the Republican Presidential nomination.

headline.main: Doles Report as Much as $7.7 Million in Assets, Most Mrs. Dole's

docs.lead_paragraph: Four weeks after President Clinton endorsed Wisconsin's radical proposal to abolish welfare, citing it as an example of the "quiet revolution" in social policy occurring across America, Administration officials say they now have doubts and concerns about some of its most important provisions. The officials said they still believed that the Federal Government and the State of Wisconsin could ultimately reach an agreement permitting the state to transform its cash assistance program into an elaborate job program for poor people.

headline.main: Clinton Wavers After Backing Welfare Plan
